text: - So, it's Trevor James here today.

And today I am really
lucky, I've been invited

to a local family's house
here in the little town
near Si Gung Young Chang.

Beautiful mountain range
here in western Sichuan.
And we are going to have some awesome,
delicious food here.
So, what are we gonna try?
(speaking in foreign language)
(instrumental music)

I can honestly say, that
eating with this family,
was an experience of a life time.
Everything was prepared differently,
and the flavors were out of this world.
They had their own wooden stove wok,
which they steam potatoes in
and their own homemade steamed buns
which were placed on the side of the wok
and would crisp brown on the outside
and stay fluffy and soft on the inside.

But, the dish that left
the biggest impression
was their own family raised yak meat.
Dried and covered in green onions, salt,
chili oil, and a sichuan peppercorn,

and then all mixed through,
damn, that was good.

The yak butter tea was
also really awesome,

out of this world, it all
begins with the walnuts.
(speaking in foreign language)
You heard it, walnuts are cracked open,
and grinded in a mortar and pestle,

and then put into a long
churn, along with some salt,
a little roasted highland barley flour,
some milk, crack an egg in there,
and now here comes the magic,
some of that sour and salty yak butter.

Finally, some red tea
is added to the churn.

And it's all mixed up for
about 10 to 15 minutes
before it's poured into a large tea pot.
(speaking in foreign language)
A little yak butter, on the potato.
(speaking in foreign language)
The yak meat is awesome.
Its like a toffee dried beef,

but its more smokey
flavored and really spicy.
(speaking in foreign language)
Along with these mind blowing flavors,

the real treat was to
taste the staple food
of the Tibetan people, tsampa.

It's made by leaving
a little butter tea in

the bottom of your bowl, and
adding a little yak butter,
and a hearty tsampa flour.

Which is roasted highland
barley flour and ghee.
Then, it's all mixed together by hand
and into finger sized snacks.
Don't take these for a small bite,

they fill you up quick, and
they're super high in calories.
Perfect for the mountains.

Especially when washed down
with more buttered tea.
(speaking in foreign language)

It's like a dry chewy, sour,
pasty it's almost pasty,
buttery, little nugget of joy.
(speaking in foreign language)

Thank you very much for watching
my food and travel videos.
It really means a lot to me.
But I also have to have a huge thank you,

for the family here at Si
Geun Young Chang, in China.

I am just so grateful to come
here and eat the awesome food.
(speaking in foreign language)
So, stay tuned I've got more fun,

food and travel videos
coming out every week.

Right now we're gonna go
check out the mountains.
Thanks again.
Please let me know what you thought about

And if you liked it,
please give me a thumbs up,
